newsitem.title: USA: Special prosecutor defends lengthy probe of Espy.
newsitem.headline: Special prosecutor defends lengthy probe of Espy.

text.p: The independent prosecutor investigating allegations of misconduct by former Clinton Administration Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy on Thursday defended the nearly three-year-long probe and said he would complete it "fairly, vigorously and expeditiously."

"This investigation is in fact about big business and powerful individuals illegally buying and attempting to buy access to a member of the president's cabinet who regulates their industry," said Donald Smaltz, who was appointed independent counsel in August 1994 to investigate Espy.
Smaltz issued a statement responding to a story in the June 16 issue of Time magazine, which said the probe has cost taxpayers more than $9 million with little to show for it.

Earlier this month, a federal judge granted a new trial to convicted Tyson Foods lobbyist Jack Williams after Smaltz's prosecutors failed to tell Williams' lawyers that a key FBI witness had admitted lying under oath in an unrelated matter.

In March, another federal judge dismissed Smaltz's case against Espy's brother because of lack of evidence to show Henry Espy had defrauded election officials when running for Mike Espy's former congressional seat.

But Smaltz said the magazine did not mention his team's criminal convictions of three corporations, five individuals and one law firm, plus the collection of more than $3.5 million in fines. The convictions are related to gifts given to Espy or his brother to win access and influence decisions, he said.
The Time magazine story said Smaltz was expected to complete his investigation this summer with possible indictments against Espy and Tyson Foods.

"Notwithstanding Time's unfounded criticism and efforts to trivialize this investigation even before its conclusion, I will continue to perform the duties for which I was appointed fairly, vigorously and expeditiously," Smaltz said.
